clinical_relevance: Suggests potential Mismatch Repair associated disease. Eg. Lynch Syndrome (especially in colorectal, endometrial, and other cancers).
May predict better response to immunotherapy (e.g., checkpoint inhibitors like pembrolizumab).
May influence treatment choices and prognosis.

underlying_results.ngs-based-test: MSI score is often reported as a percentage or score (e.g., from 0 to 1 or 0 to 100%). >= 0.20 (or >= 20%) is considered MSI-High

microsatellite-instability-low.definition: Only 1 of several tested microsatellite loci is unstable.
microsatellite-instability-low.implication: Generally considered not clinically significant on its own.
clinical_relevance: Rarely linked to mismatch repair defects.
May be considered borderline in some contexts, but often doesn’t affect treatment.
report_language: Indeterminate MSI - sometimes used if data is borderline or not clearly MSI-H or MSS

underlying_result.ngs-based-test: MSI score is often reported as a percentage or score (e.g., from 0 to 1 or 0 to 100%). 0.10-0.19 (or ~10-19%) - MSI-Low

microsatellite-instability-stable.definition: No instability detected at tested loci.
clinical_relevance: Less likely to benefit from immunotherapy.
Suggests that other pathways (e.g., chromosomal instability) may be driving tumorigenesis.

underlying_result.ngs-based-test: MSI score is often reported as a percentage or score (e.g., from 0 to 1 or 0 to 100%). <0.10 (or <10%) - Microsatellite Stable

microsatellite-instability-indeterminate.definition: Status cannot be confidently classified as MSI-High, MSI-Low, or MSS due to borderline, inconclusive, or technically insufficient results.
microsatellite-instability-indeterminate.implication: Further testing or repeat analysis required; this category does not provide actionable diagnostic or treatment guidance on its own.
clinical_relevance: May arise from poor sample quality, low tumor content, or ambiguous molecular results.
Should prompt re-evaluation using alternate methods (e.g., IHC for MMR proteins, repeat MSI testing, or alternative NGS panels).
In some cases, clinical judgment may guide treatment decisions pending further clarification.

underlying_result.pcr-based-tests: Inconclusive due to poor amplification or insufficient loci evaluated. Results that do not meet clear thresholds for MSI-H, MSI-L, or MSS.
underlying_result.ngs-based-test: MSI score is often reported as a percentage or score (e.g., from 0 to 1 or 0 to 100%). MSI score in the range of 0.10–0.19 (10–19%) when not clearly meeting MSI-Low criteria. Low confidence or quality flags from variant calling pipeline or insufficient coverage.
